pageData.text: Due to scientific advances in the understanding of the nature of electricity, the modern world has many useful and essential electronic devices. Free falling objects demonstrate gravitational force and its ability to move large objects at high speeds, but the electric forces that hold the microscopic atom together are many times more powerful. In this investigation, you will investigate the fundamental properties of electric charge and observe the electric force.

pageData.text: In the United States every year, between 50 to 300 are killed from being struck by lightning, with hundreds more being injured<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. Although in a thunderstorm, thunder is often heard before the lightning is seen; lightning actually creates the thunder sound. Lightning is a spark of electricity in the atmosphere between clouds, air, and the ground. Air particles act as <button class='glossary-text'>insulators</button> between the positive and negative charges in the clouds and between the clouds and the ground. When opposite charges build up enough, the air’s insulating capacity stops working. Lightning is the rapid discharge of electricity, which temporarily equalizes the charged regions. The lightning channel releases heat and warms the air to about 50,000 degrees Fahrenheit, which causes the air to explode outward. The pressure in the initial outward shock wave becomes called thunder.

Although thunderstorms can have many devastating impacts (i.e., death/injury, flooding, and fires), there is a benefit for plants.  About 78% of the Earth’s atmosphere is nitrogen, however, plants can’t use nitrogen in this form. The energy created during a lightning event is enough to separate the nitrogen atoms. Once separated they fall to Earth and combine with minerals to form nitrates, which can be used by plants to grow.

1Zemaitis, M.R., Foris, L.A., Lopez, R.A., et al. (9 September 2022). Electrical Injuries. StatPearls.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448087/

pageData.altText: Multiple cloud-to-ground lightning strikes during a night-time thunderstorm.

pageData.text: The existence of was known to the ancient Greeks; the word electricity comes from elektron, the Greek word for amber. It is probable that clothing fibers clung to jewelry made from the resinous substance amber. Attempting to remove the fibers involved rubbing them which made the situation worse as you may have experienced with static cling. Static electricity is a simple example of electric force, which can overcome the force of gravity, as illustrated in Figure 1 by the lifting of a child’s hair straight into the air.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: hair standing up due to static electricity

pageData.text: Significant advances in understanding would be required to explain the observations of static electricity in terms of positive and negative electrical charge. An American, Benjamin Franklin (1706–1790), experimented with charges, collecting electric charges from thunderstorm clouds using a kite with wet string. Through these experiments, Benjamin Franklin proved storm clouds carried electricity and lightning was a very heavily charged spark of electricity. Benjamin Franklin is credited with naming the two types of electrical charges as ‘positive’ and ‘negative’.

Electric charge is a fundamental quantity that underlies all electrical phenomena. In nature, the fundamental particle that has a positive charge is the <button class='glossary-text'>proton</button>, which is located in the nuclei of atoms. The fundamental particle that has a negative charge is the <button class='glossary-text'>electron</button>, which is located in the electron cloud surrounding the nucleus of an atom. At the time Benjamin Franklin studied electric charge, we did not understand that there were protons and electrons in atoms. However, Benjamin Franklin discovered like charges repelled each other and opposite charges attracted each other; meaning charged objects exert forces on each other.

Have you ever built up a static charge walking across a carpet? If you then touch an object (typically metal) that has an opposite charge, you get shocked as <button class='glossary-text'>electrons</button> attracted to positive charges literally “jump” towards it. Positively charged objects gain electrons and the negatively charged objects lose electrons so the charged objects can return to a state of neutral charge. A loss of <button class='glossary-text'>static electricity</button> as electric charge is transferred from one object to another is called <button class='glossary-text'>static discharge</button>. Static electricity can build up when you comb your hair on a very dry, cold day and seems to stand up. The process of combing your hair causes a buildup of “like” charges; the like charges repel each other and your hair strands “stand” up.

To explain static charge, start with an object, made of atoms; every atom has the same number of <button class='glossary-text'>protons</button> and electrons making the object electrically neutral. If the atom is an <button class='glossary-text'>ion</button>, there is an excess of electrons or a deficiency of electrons in the atom’s outer shell. Positive ions are missing electrons in their outer shell and negative ions have excess electrons in their outer shell.

An imbalance in the number of positive and negative charges will cause the object to have either a positive or negative electric charge. It is important to note that when an object builds up a positive or negative charge, no electrons are created or destroyed; electrons are transferred from one object to another. When you comb your hair on a dry, cold day, electrons transfer from the hair to the comb. The hair has a deficiency of electrons and is said to have a positive static charge. The comb has an excess of electrons and is said to have a negative static charge.

There are four methods by which charges can redistribute themselves to build up static electricity: by <button class='glossary-text'>friction</button>, by <button class='glossary-text'>conduction</button>, by <button class='glossary-text'>induction</button>, and by <button class='glossary-text'>polarization</button>. Charging by friction is the transfer of electrons from one uncharged object to another by rubbing the two objects together. If you rub your hair with a balloon, electrons from your hair move onto the balloon, giving the balloon a negative charge.

Charging by <button class='glossary-text'>conduction</button> is the transfer of <button class='glossary-text'>electrons</button> from one object to another by direct contact, as shown in Figure 2. Charge can be built up on one object and be transferred to another object by conduction. For example, when a negatively charged balloon touches a metal ball with neutral charge, some of the electrons from the balloon will flow to the metal ball, giving it a negative charge.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: diagram showing charging by conduction

pageData.text: Charging by <button class='glossary-text'>induction</button> involves bringing an object with a static charge near to an electrically neutral object without touching it, as shown in Figure 3. The like charges in the neutral object will be pushed away from the region adjacent to the charged object and opposite charge in the neutral object will be attracted toward it. The neutral object seems to be attracted to the charged object because an opposite charge has been “induced” in it. It is important to note that the charged object never touches the neutral object.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: diagram showing charging by induction

pageData.text: Charging by <button class='glossary-text'>induction</button> is explained by the <button class='glossary-text'>electrons</button> reacting to the presence of an electric field surrounding a charged object. In some materials, like metals, electrons move more freely; if a metal object is close to a negatively charged object, electrons are repelled by the electric field of the object and move away from it. The close end of the metal object becomes positively charged, and the far end becomes negatively charged; this process is called charging by induction.

In other materials, electrons only move within their own atoms; however, the electrons will react to the presence of an electric field, resulting in individual atoms having charged ends that can be attracted to charged objects; this process is called charging by <button class='glossary-text'>polarization</button>, shown in Figure 4. Charges don’t transfer between objects in polarization or induction, so neither method changes the overall charge of objects; the alignment of the atoms creates regions within the object that have opposite charge.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: diagram showing charging by polarization

pageData.question: Which method of charging does NOT require the objects to be in direct contact with each other?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Charging by induction involves bringing an object with a static charge near to an electrically neutral object without touching it.

pageData.question: Which two methods of charging do NOT change the overall charge of the objects?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Charges don’t transfer between objects in polarization or induction, so neither method changes the overall charge of objects; the alignment of the atoms creates regions within the object that have opposite charge.

hintData.title: Hint

The like charges in the neutral object will be pushed away from the region adjacent to the charged object and opposite charge in the neutral object will be attracted toward it. The neutral object seems to be attracted to the charged object because an opposite charge has been “induced” in it. It is important to note that the charged object never touches the neutral object.

img.alt: Figure 3: diagram showing charging by induction

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Charging by induction involves bringing an object with a static charge near to an electrically neutral object without touching it, as shown in Figure 3. The like charges in the neutral object will be pushed away from the region adjacent to the charged object and opposite charge in the neutral object will be attracted toward it. The neutral object seems to be attracted to the charged object because an opposite charge has been “induced” in it. It is important to note that the charged object never touches the neutral object.

img.alt: Figure 3: diagram showing charging by induction

pageData.subTitle: Triboelectric Series
pageData.text: Whenever you rub two materials together, they become electrified and develop opposite charges. A <button class='glossary-text'>Triboelectric Series</button> ranks materials according to their tendency to gain or lose <button class='glossary-text'>electrons</button>. The items higher up on the list will lose electrons and become positively charged while those on the bottom of the list gain electrons and become negatively charged.

For example, if a glass rod is rubbed with rabbit’s fur, the glass will acquire a negative charge. However, if the same glass rod is rubbed by a rubber balloon, it will acquire a positive charge. Table 1 is an example of a Triboelectric Series of conventional materials. In a triboelectric series, materials are ranked from high to low in terms of the tendency of the material to acquire a positive charge.

If an object high up on this list (wood, like a wooden tabletop, for example) was brought into contact with an object low down on the list (cellophane tape, for example), the wooden tabletop would lose electrons to the sticky side (the side that directly contacted the wooden tabletop) of the cellophane tape. The wooden tabletop would become positively charged and the sticky side of the cellophane tape would become negatively charged. Remember Figure 4; the negative charges picked up by the sticky side of the tape contacting the wooden tabletop would influence the non-sticky side of the tape and cause the non-sticky side to become more positively charged. The further away two materials are from each other on the series, the greater the charge transferred. Materials in the middle of the list (paper and cotton, for example) have a strong tendency not to give up or accept electrons.

pageData.subTitle: Electrostatic Forces and Coulomb’s Law
pageData.text: The interactions of charge, attraction of opposite charges and repulsion of like charges, results from force being exerted on the charges. This force was described by French physicist Charles Coulomb (1736–1806) and is known as . The Coulomb law relationship states the electrostatic force is directly proportional to the amount of charge on the objects and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them. The amount of charge on each object is given by q1 and q2, with the distance between them given as r. The Coulomb’s law relationship is expressed in Equation 1.

pageData.altText: Equation 1: force sub electric equals begin fraction k q1 times q2 over r squared end fraction

pageData.text: The proportionality constant, k, in Equation 1, also known as the Coulomb’s law constant, is equal to 8.99 x 109 Nm 2/C2. Force is a vector quantity with SI units of Newtons [N] and a direction dependent on the type of charges. If both charges have the same sign, the force between them is repulsive; the charges will move away from each other. If the charges have opposite signs, the force between them is attractive; the charges will move toward each other.

The amount of charge, q1 and q2, is measured in a unit called the Coulomb (C). The fundamental physical constant expressing the naturally occurring amount of electric charge on an is e or qe = -1.602 x 10-19 C and on a is qp = +1.602 x 10-19 C. The charge on an object comes in multiples of these numbers; for example, a particle that has a charge of +100 C is deficient in the number of electrons equal to 100 C times 1.602 x 10-19 C or 6.25 x 1020 electrons.

The electrostatic force is directly related to the amount of charge on the objects. If the amount of charge on one object doubles, the electrostatic force will double and if the charge on both objects doubles the electrostatic force will quadruple. The electrostatic force is inversely related to the distance between charges; increasing the distance between the charges by two (r = 2r ) will result in the force being decreased by 1 /4. If the separation is decreased by a factor of 2 (r = r / 2), the force between the charges will increase by a factor of four.
In the Electrostatics investigation you will observe the Coulomb’s law force through the interaction of electrically charged objects.

pageData.question: The electrostatic force between two objects is represented by F. If you double the distance between the two objects, what will the new force be?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Doubling the distance means we can represent the distance as “2r”. This value is squared in Coulomb’s Law, so force will decrease by a factor of 4 as you double the distance.

pageData.question: Two identical charges repel each other with a force of 4 N. If the distance between the charges is halved, what will the new force be?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If you decrease the distance between the two charges, the force will increase. If the distance is halved, the force will be 16 N.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The electrostatic force is directly related to the amount of charge on the objects. If the amount of charge on one object doubles, the electrostatic force will double and if the charge on both objects doubles the electrostatic force will quadruple. The electrostatic force is inversely related to the distance between charges; increasing the distance between the charges by two (r = 2r ) will result in the force being decreased by ¼. If the separation is decreased by a factor of 2 (r = r /2), the force between the charges will increase by a factor of four.

img.alt: Equation 1: force sub electric equals begin fraction k q1 times q2 over r squared end fraction

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The electrostatic force is directly related to the amount of charge on the objects. If the amount of charge on one object doubles, the electrostatic force will double and if the charge on both objects doubles the electrostatic force will quadruple. The electrostatic force is inversely related to the distance between charges; increasing the distance between the charges by two (r = 2r ) will result in the force being decreased by ¼. If the separation is decreased by a factor of 2 (r = r /2), the force between the charges will increase by a factor of four.

img.alt: Equation 1: force sub electric equals begin fraction k q1 times q2 over r squared end fraction

pageData.subTitle: Conductors and Insulators
pageData.text: The behavior of an object that has been charged is dependent upon whether the object is made of a conductive or a nonconductive material. <button class='glossary-text'>Conductors</button> allow for charge transfer through the free movement of <button class='glossary-text'>electrons</button>. Conductors are materials that permit electrons to flow freely from particle to particle; conducting materials will permit charge to be transferred across the entire surface of the object. If excess charge is transferred to the object at a one location, the charge is quickly distributed across the entire surface of the object by movement of electrons. until the overall repulsive forces between the excess electrons is minimized. Examples of conductors include silver, gold, copper, steel, and seawater.

In contrast to conductors, <button class='glossary-text'>insulators</button> are materials that impede the free flow of electrons from atom to atom and molecule to molecule. If charge is transferred to an insulator at one location, the excess charge will remain at the initial location. The molecules of the insulator do not permit the free flow of electrons; subsequently charge is not often distributed evenly across the surface of an insulator. Examples of insulators include rubber, glass, diamonds, air, and dry wood.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of Activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning, make pith balls and suspend them from the table. In Activity 1, make tape strips with handles, attach the tape strips in the given configuration, quickly remove the tape strips and bring the non-sticky sides together. Once you have tested all of the configurations of tape strips, attach the tape strips in the given configuration and inflate the balloon by rubbing it with the plastic bag. Then, quickly remove the tape strips, bring the non-sticky side close to the balloon and observe what occurred. Next, photograph the interaction of the tape and the balloon. Once you have tested both tape configurations, cut squares of paper and scatter them over the surface. Then, rub one object with another object and bring it close to the pieces of paper. Next, record the number of pieces of paper picked up by the charged object. Once you have tested all of the combinations, proceed to Activity 2.

A map of the procedural workflow of Activity 2 of this investigation. After completing Activity 1, in Activity 2, you will charge the comb by rubbing it with the plastic bag. Then, you will bring it close to the pith balls and observe their behavior. Next, you will recharge the comb bring it close to the pith balls and observe their behavior. Then, you will record a video of the behavior of the pith balls. Next, you will repeat the process with the balloon. Then, you will charge the comb by rubbing it with the plastic bag. Next, you will touch the comb to the pith ball. Then, you will recharge the comb, bring it close to the pith balls and observe their behavior. Next, you will record a video of the behavior of the pith balls. Finally, you will repeat the process with the balloon.

Wear your safety goggles at all times while conducting this investigation. Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this investigation. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after the investigation and clean up the work area with soap and water after finishing. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: An atom has a net neutral charge initially.  If it transfers an electron from its outer edge to another atom, what is the charge of the original atom?
Why does a rubber balloon stick to a wall after you rub it on your hair?

options.text: There is an attractive electric force between the wall and the balloon.
There is a repulsive electric force between the wall and the balloon.
Both the wall and the balloon have positive charges.
Both the wall and the balloon have negative charges.

assestmentData.question: What is the term used to describe materials that hold electrons very tightly and impede the free flow of electrons?
In wintertime, we tend to observe more static electricity than in the summer.  Why is this the case?

options.text: Electrons conduct more easily in cold, dry air.
Electrons conduct more easily in cold, humid air.
Electrons conduct more easily in warm, humid air.
Electrons conduct more easily in warm, dry air.
Electrons conduct more easily in cold air, regardless of the humidity level.

assestmentData.question: A solid conducting sphere is given a positive charge equal to q. How is the charge q distributed in or on the sphere?

options.text: It is uniformly distributed on the surface of the sphere.
It is concentrated at the center of the sphere.
Its density decreases radially outward from the center.
Its density increases radially outward from the center.

assestmentData.question: A plastic comb with an unknown charge attracts a pith ball.  Which of the following could describe this phenomenon?

options.text: The plastic comb has a negative charge, and the pith ball has a positive charge.
Both objects have a positive charge.
Both objects have a negative charge.

assestmentData.question: How does the magnitude of the gravitational attraction between two protons compare to the magnitude of the electrostatic repulsion between the two protons?

options.text: The gravitational attraction is much smaller.
The gravitational attraction is much larger.
The gravitational attraction is the same as the electrostatic repulsion.
There is no gravitational attraction between the protons.

assestmentData.question: Two identical charges repel each other with a force of 4 N. If the distance between the charges is halved, what will the new force be?

Create a work space. You will be using a flat surface like a tabletop or countertop; it must be safe for you to adhere tape to the surface and remove it without damaging the surface. Test your surface with a small piece of tape to ensure no damage will result from conducting this procedure.
Read through the procedure.
Gather the needed materials.
Certain environmental conditions are more conducive for <button class='glossary-text'>static electricity</button>. If possible, choose a day to do your lab that is cool and dry.
Watch the following video on how to set up video recordings for physics experiments:

For consistent results, you will need to be careful while handling the materials, so please follow the directions as closely as possible.
For Activity 1
  • When you are instructed to make a strip of tape, cut a piece from your roll of tape approximately 20 cm long and fold over approximately 1 cm of one end of the tape to form a non-sticky handle, as shown in Figure 5.

For Activity 2
  • Make two pith balls from your aluminum foil balls, foam balls or small amount of foam (like a piece of a foam cup or a packing peanut). The pith ball can be cylindrical or spherical, approximately 1.5 cm diameter (length).
  • Cut the approximately 60-cm-long string in half; tie a piece of string around each pith ball and suspend the pith balls over the edge of a table. Secure the non-pith ball end of the string to the table with a piece of tape. The pith balls should be 2 to 3 cm apart and able to move freely.
  • Ensure there is no initial charge on the pith balls by touching them with your fingers.

In Activity 1, you will observe the behavior of strips of tape and balloons to explore charge and electrostatic force. You will then attempt to charge various objects with other objects and pick up small pieces of paper to determine which materials transfer charge and which do not.

pageData.text: Make a strip of tape and stick the entire sticky surface of the tape to your flat surface (tabletop or countertop); use the ink pen to mark the handle of this piece of tape with a “1.”
Note: Remember each strip of tape should be made according to Preparation Step 5.

Make another strip of tape and stick the entire sticky surface of the tape to your flat surface (tabletop or countertop) at least 15 cm away from your first strip of tape; use the ink pen to mark the handle of this piece of tape with a “2.”
Grab hold of the handle of each strip of tape and very quickly pull off both strips of tape from the surface, keeping the pieces of tape at least 15 cm apart.
Carefully bring the non-sticky sides of the pieces of tape together and record observations about the behavior of the pieces in Data Table 1 in the Lab Notebook.
Discard these pieces of tape.

Make a strip of tape and stick the entire sticky surface of the tape to your flat surface (tabletop or countertop). Use the ink pen to mark the handle of the tape as “B1” (B will be used to represent a bottom piece of tape).

Make another strip of tape and stick the entire sticky surface of the tape on top of the B1 piece of tape. Use the ink pen to mark the handle of the tape as “T1” (T will be used to represent a top piece of tape).

Make a strip of tape and stick the entire sticky surface of the tape to your flat surface (tabletop or countertop) at least 15 cm away from your B1 and T1 pieces of tape. Use the ink pen to mark the handle of the tape as “B2.”
Make another strip of tape and stick the entire sticky surface of the tape on top of the B2 piece of tape. Use the ink pen to mark the handle of the tape as “T2.”
Use the handle of tape T1 and very quickly pull off the T1 strip of tape from tape B1.
Use the handle of tape B1 and very quickly pull off the B1 strip of tape from the flat surface. Keep tape B1 and T1 separated.

Bring the non-sticky sides of B1 and T1 towards each other but do not let them touch. Record your observations about the behavior of T1 and B1 in Data Table 1. If the pieces of tapes touch, repeat Steps 6 and 7 to make another T1 and B1. Conduct Steps 10–12 again until observations can be made without the tape samples touching.

Set the T1 and B1 pieces of tape, non-sticky side down, on the flat surface approximately 15 cm away from each other and approximately 15 cm away from tapes B2 and T2. Do not stick them back on the table.
Use the handle of tape T2 and very quickly pull off the T2 strip of tape from tape B2.
Use the handle of tape B2 and very quickly pull off the B2 strip from the flat surface. Keep tape B2 and T2 separated.

Bring the non-sticky sides of B2 and T2 towards each other but do not let them touch. Record your observations about the behavior of T2 and B2 in Data Table 1. If the pieces of tapes touch, repeat Steps 8 and 9 to make another T2 and B2, and conduct Steps 14–16 again until observations can be made without the tape samples touching.

Take a picture of the interaction between the tapes for inclusion in the Lab Notebook. If a second person is unavailable, you can secure tape T2 to the edge of a tabletop with a piece of tape secured to the handle and the other to the tabletop edge (loosely hanging so there is freedom of movement). This will allow one hand to be available for the interaction and the other hand to take a picture.
Set the T2 and B2 pieces of tape, non-sticky side down, on the flat surface approximately 15 cm away from each other and approximately 15 cm away from T1 and B1. Do not stick them back on the table.

Pick up tape T1 and B2, but carefully bring the non-sticky sides towards each other. Do not let them touch. Record your observations about the behavior of tapes T1 and B2 in Data Table 1. Replace tapes T1 and B2 non-sticky side down approximately 15 cm away from each other and approximately 15 cm away from T2 and B1.

Pick up tape T2 and B1, carefully bring the non-sticky sides together. Do not let them touch. Record your observations about the behavior of tapes T2 and B1 in Data Table 1. Replace tapes T2 and B1 non-sticky side down approximately 15 cm away from each other and approximately 15 cm away from T1 and B2.

Pick up tape T1 and T2 and carefully bring the non-sticky sides towards each other. Do not let them touch. Record your observations about the behavior of tapes T1 and T2 in Data Table 1. Replace tapes T1 and T2 non-sticky side down approximately 15 cm away from each other and approximately 15 cm away from B1 and B2.
Pick up tape B1 and B2, carefully bring the non-sticky sides towards each other, but do not let them touch. Record your observations about the behavior of tapes B1 and B2 in Data Table 1.
Discard all the pieces of tape.
Make a strip of tape and stick the entire sticky surface of the tape to your flat surface (tabletop or countertop). Use the ink pen to mark the handle of the tape as “B.”
Make another strip of tape and stick the entire sticky surface of the tape on top of the B piece of tape. Use the ink pen to mark the handle of the tape as “T.”

Use the handle of tape T and very quickly pull off the T strip of tape from tape B. Bring the non-sticky side of tape T close to your arm hair; record your observations of what happens to the tape and your arm hair in Data Table 1. Discard tape T.

Use the handle of tape B and very quickly pull off the B strip of tape from the flat surface; bring the non-sticky side of tape B close to your arm hair; record your observations of what happens to the tape and your arm hair in Data Table 1. Discard tape B.

typeBefore.title:
B
 Identifying Charge with Transparent Tape and Balloon (12 steps)

pageData.text: Make a strip of tape and stick the entire sticky surface of the tape to your flat surface (tabletop or countertop).Use the ink pen to mark the handle of the tape as “B.”
Make another strip of tape and stick the entire sticky surface of the tape on top of the B piece of tape. Use the ink pen to mark the handle of the tape as “T.”

Use the handle of tape T and very quickly pull off the T strip of tape from tape B. Place the non-sticky side of T down on the flat surface approximately 15 cm away from tape B. Do not stick it back on the table.

Use the handle of tape B and very quickly pull off the B strip of tape from the flat surface. Place the non-sticky side of B down on the flat surface approximately 15 cm away from tape T. Do not stick it back on the table.

Blow up a balloon approximately half-full. Pinch the end of the balloon closed with one hand and use the other hand to vigorously rub the balloon with the plastic bag for at least 20 seconds. This will place a negative charge on the balloon.
Still holding the balloon closed, pick up tape T and bring the non-sticky side of tape T close to the balloon and observe the behavior of the tape. Replace tape T.
Record your observations of the behavior of tape T, as it was brought close to the balloon in Data Table 2.

Take a picture of the interaction between tape T and the balloon for inclusion in the Lab Notebook. If a second person is unavailable, you can secure tape T to the edge of a tabletop with a piece of tape secured to the handle and the other to the tabletop edge (loosely hanging so there is freedom of movement). This will allow one hand to be available for the interaction and the other hand to take a picture.

Still holding the balloon closed, pick up tape B and bring the non-sticky side of tape B close to the balloon and observe the behavior of the tape. Replace tape B and release your hold on the balloon and set it aside.
Record your observations of the behavior of tape B as it was brought close to the balloon in Data Table 2.

Take a picture of the interaction between tape B and the balloon for inclusion in the Lab Notebook. If a second person is unavailable, you can secure tape B to the edge of a tabletop with a piece of tape secured to the handle and the other to the tabletop edge (loosely hanging so there is freedom of movement). This will allow one hand to be available for the interaction and the other hand to take a picture.
You can now discard the T and B pieces of tape.
Cut a piece of paper into small pieces (approximately 1 cm squares) and scatter them in a small area on your flat surface.
Use the plastic comb and rub it vigorously for at least 20 seconds with the cotton cloth.

Bring the plastic comb close to the small pieces of paper. Use your cell phone (or other video recording device) to take a video of the interaction between the comb and the pieces of paper for inclusion in the Lab Notebook

Record your observations about the behavior of the small pieces of paper; if paper was attracted to the comb, record the number of pieces of paper that were picked up in Data Table 3. Remove the pieces of paper from the comb.
Use the plastic comb and rub it vigorously for at least 20 seconds with the plastic bag.
Bring the plastic comb close to the small pieces of paper. Take a video of the interaction between the comb and the pieces of paper for inclusion in the Lab Notebook.

Record your observations about the behavior of the small pieces of paper; if paper was attracted to the comb, record the number of pieces of paper that were picked up in Data Table 3. Remove the pieces of paper from the comb.
Use the rubber item and rub it vigorously for at least 20 seconds with the cotton cloth.
Bring the rubber item close to the small pieces of paper.

Record your observations about the behavior of the small pieces of paper; if paper was attracted to the rubber item, record the number of pieces of paper that were picked up in Data Table 3. Remove the pieces of paper from the rubber item.
Use the rubber item and rub it vigorously for at least 20 seconds with the plastic bag.
Bring the rubber item close to the small pieces of paper.
Record your observations about the behavior of the small pieces of paper; if paper was attracted to the rubber item, record the number of pieces of paper that were picked up in Data Table 3.
Use a glass or jar and rub it vigorously for at least 20 seconds with the cotton cloth.
Bring the glass or jar close to the small pieces of paper.

Record your observations about the behavior of the small pieces of paper; if paper was attracted to the glass or jar, record the number of pieces of paper that were picked up in Data Table 3. Remove the pieces of paper from the glass or jar.
Use your glass or jar and rub it vigorously for at least 20 seconds with the plastic bag.
Bring the glass or jar close to the small pieces of paper.
Record your observations about the behavior of the small pieces of paper; if paper was attracted to the glass or jar, record the number of pieces of paper that were picked up in Data Table 3.

In Activity 2, you will use a comb and a balloon to charge pith balls by <button class='glossary-text'>induction</button> and then by <button class='glossary-text'>polarization</button>. You will then observe the behavior of the charged pith balls when close to other charged objects.

pages.title: Observing Electric Charge Using Induction and Polarization
pages.pageTitle: Observing Electric Charge Using Induction and Polarization

pageData.text: Charge the plastic comb by rubbing it vigorously for at least 20 seconds with the plastic bag.

Bring the comb near to the outside (to the right) of the pith ball on your right but do not touch it. Record your observation of the behavior of the pith balls due to the presence of the charged comb in Data Table 4.
Charge the plastic comb again by rubbing it vigorously for at least 20 seconds with the plastic bag.

Bring the comb near to the outside (to the left) of the pith ball on your left but do not touch it. Record your observation of the behavior of the pith balls to the presence of the charged comb in Data Table 4.
Use your cell phone (or other video recording device) to take a video of the behavior of the pith balls. A link to the video will need to be included in the Lab Notebook.
Discharge the pith balls by touching them with your fingers.
Repeat Steps 1–6 using a half blown-up balloon in place of the plastic comb.
Discharge the pith balls by touching them with your fingers.
Charge the plastic comb by rubbing it vigorously for at least 20 seconds with the plastic bag.

Bring the comb next to the outside (to the right) of the pith ball on your right, touching it. Record your observation of the behavior of the pith balls due to the presence of the charged comb in Data Table 5.
Charge the plastic comb again by rubbing it vigorously for at least 20 seconds with the plastic bag.

Move the comb from underneath the pith balls to between them but do not touch either pith ball. Observe and record the behavior of the pith balls. Record your observations in Data Table 5. If you touch a pith ball repeat the process of discharging both balls and charging the right pith ball as described in Steps 1 and 2.
Charge a half-filled balloon by rubbing it vigorously for at least 20 seconds with the plastic bag.

Bring the balloon next to the outside (to the right) of the pith ball on your right, touching it. Record your observation of the behavior of the pith balls to the presence of the charged balloon in Data Table 5.
Charge the half-filled balloon again by rubbing it vigorously for at least 20 seconds with the plastic bag.

Move the balloon from underneath the pith balls toward them. When the pith balls begin to move, hold the balloon in place; the balloon should not touch either pith ball. Record your observation of the behavior of the pith balls due to the presence of the charged balloon in Data Table 5.
Use your cell phone (or other video recording device) to take a video of the behavior of the pith balls. A link to the video will be included in the Lab Notebook. Clean up your work space.
Return the materials to the equipment kit, and clean the area.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.title: Data Table 1. Exploring Charge with Transparent Tape

text: Describe the interaction between the top and bottom strips of tape as the relate to electric charge.
Describe the interaction between two top and two bottom strips of tape as they relate to electric charge.
Usually arm hair is neutral; it has an equal number of positive and negative charges.  Explain why both the top tape and the bottom tape were attracted to your arm hair.

Using the interactions in Data Table 1, the properties of electric charge, and triboelectric effects, explain how to determine which strips of tape, top and bottom, carry a positive charge or a negative charge.
Explain how the electric force changed as the strips of tape were brought closer to each other.

pageData.title: Data Table 2. Identifying Charge with Transparent Tape and Balloon

text: Using the observations from Data Table 2, identify the type of charge on Tape T. Justify your answer using the fundamental properties of charge.  Record your type of charge in Data Table 2.
Using the observations from Data Table 2, identify the type of charge on Tape B. Justify your answer using the fundamental properties of charge.  Record your type of charge in Data Table 2.
Explain how the two kinds of tape, T and B, acquired the charges that you observed.  Identify and describe the method of charging
Clearly state what fundamental properties of charging are demonstrated by the interaction of the balloon and the pieces of tape.

Using the identification of the type of charge on T-pieces and of tape and B-pieces of tape, review your observation of the interactions in Data Table 1.  Are your observations in agreement with the type of charge on the different pieces of tape?  For any interactions that are not in agreement, describe why it did not display the expected interaction.

header.text: Number of Pieces of Paper Picked Up

text: Compare the charge on the items when they were charged by the cloth and the plastic bag.  Explain why one material placed more charge on an item than the other material.

Compare the electric force exerted by the charged items on the pieces of paper when an item was charged by the cloth and the plastic bag.  Explain why charging with one material resulted in a greater electrical force than when the same item was charged by the other material.

text: Consider Data tables 3 and 4.  Identify the instances where the right pith ball experienced attraction and explain why for each instance.
Identify two observations that demonstrate the right pith ball was charged after it came in contact with the plastic comb and balloon during Activity 2B.
Can you determine what type of charge is on each pith ball if they are attracted to each other after the charged comb or balloon is brough close to the right pith ball? Explain your answer.

A map of the procedural workflow of Activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning, make pith balls and suspend them from the table. In Activity 1, make tape strips with handles, attach the tape strips in the given configuration, quickly remove the tape strips and bring the non-sticky sides together. Once you have tested all of the configurations of tape strips, attach the tape strips in the given configuration and inflate the balloon by rubbing it with the plastic bag. Then, quickly remove the tape strips, bring the non-sticky side close to the balloon and observe what occurred. Next, photograph the interaction of the tape and the balloon. Once you have tested both tape configurations, cut squares of paper and scatter them over the surface. Then, rub one object with another object and bring it close to the pieces of paper. Next, record the number of pieces of paper picked up by the charged object. Once you have tested all of the combinations, proceed to Activity 2.

A map of the procedural workflow of Activity 2 of this investigation. After completing Activity 1, in Activity 2, you will charge the comb by rubbing it with the plastic bag. Then, you will bring it close to the pith balls and observe their behavior. Next, you will recharge the comb bring it close to the pith balls and observe their behavior. Then, you will record a video of the behavior of the pith balls. Next, you will repeat the process with the balloon. Then, you will charge the comb by rubbing it with the plastic bag. Next, you will touch the comb to the pith ball. Then, you will recharge the comb, bring it close to the pith balls and observe their behavior. Next, you will record a video of the behavior of the pith balls. Finally, you will repeat the process with the balloon.

pageData.content: Figure 5. Creating tape strips with handles

data.title: Conduction
data.content: Direct contact between objects; transfer of electrons results in charging

data.title: Conductor
data.content: Any material that permits electrons to flow freely from particle to particle; the resulting charge can be transferred across the entire surface of the object

data.title: Coulomb's law
data.content: The electrostatic force is directly proportional to the amount of charge on the objects and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them

data.title: Electron
data.content: A fundamental particle that has a negative charge

data.title: Friction
data.content: Caused by rubbing two objects together; a transfer in electrons that results in charging

data.title: Induction
data.content: Inducing a charge in an object by bringing a charged object near it without touching it

data.title: Insulator
data.content: Any material that impedes the free flow of electrons from atom to atom and molecule to molecule

data.title: Ion
data.content: An atom or molecule with a net electric charge due to the loss or gain of one or more electrons

data.title: Polarization
data.content: Individual atoms align themselves with an electric field

data.title: Proton
data.content: A fundamental particle that has a positive charge

data.title: Static discharge
data.content: A loss of static electricity due to the transfer of electric charge from one object to another

data.title: Static electricity
data.content: A stationary electric charge, typically produced by friction, which causes sparks or crackling or the attraction of dust or hair

data.title: Triboelectric Series
data.content: Ranks materials according to their tendency to gain or lose electrons
